newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX heating oil ends off on increasing output.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX heating oil ends off on increasing output.

text.p: NYMEX heating oil extended its decline Wednesday after oil inventory data showed higher distillate output when heating oil supply was already deemed ample amid mild weather.

"The main feature of the day was weakness in the refined product contracts, with refinery runs up more than one percent when distributors are trying to de-stock heat," said Jim Ritterbusch, a dealer with Sweeney Oil.
March heat ended off 0.86 cent at 63.32 cents after falling 1.10 cents Tuesday. March gasoline ended off 0.77 cent a gallon at 67.54 cents.
March crude ended off 11 cents at $23.91 a barrel.
Crude's declines were limited by higher refinery operating rates amid relatively tight crude supply, dealers said.
Oil inventory data released by American Petroleum Institute (API) on Tuesday said crude stocks were down 9.60 million barrels below a year ago for the week ended January 31.
The API said refinery capacity utilization rates rose 1.2 percentage points for the week to 90.3 percent when traders had been expecting the rate to decline by 0.5 percentage point.
Dealers said the higher run rate combined with gasoline stocks growing a larger-than-expected 2.9 million barrels led to selling in the refined product crack spreads.
The March gasoline to crude crack fell to $4.48 a barrel from $4.67 Tuesday while the March heating oil crack spread fell to $2.70 a barrel from $2.94 Tuesday.

According to the API data, output of distillate, which includes heating oil and diesel, grew to 3.20 million barrels from 3.10 million just when distillate stocks were showing a surplus with year ago levels for the first time since June 1995.
Heating oil output grew to 1.40 million barrels from 1.37 million barrels.
Meanwhile, mild temperatures in the northeastern United States, the largest heating oil market in the world, are tempering heat demand, dealers said.
Independent forecaster Weather Services Corp expected temperatures to average normal to above normal through the weekend in the Northeast.
-- Harry Milling, New York Energy Desk, 212-859-1761
